ancestors.content:
“Last year’s record highs were the hottest the planet has been in about 120,000 years. Now the first six months of 2024 have broken even those. Scientists blame the supercharged heat mostly on #climatechange from the burning of #coal, #oil and #naturalgas and on #livestock #agriculture.” (From https://www.pbs.org/newshour/science/last-sunday-was-earths-hottest-day-in-recorded-history)

And the #Paris #Olympics could be a super-spreader for Dengue fever thanks to our rising temperatures. (From https://www.bbc.co.uk/sounds/play/m0021b06)

But let’s keep ploughing ahead living the lives that have got us in this mess, which is only going to get worse and worse. 👍

MORE GROWTH. MORE FOSSIL FUELS. DEFINITELY MORE AI. WE LOOOOOVE PUNISHMENT!

Keep flying. 👍 Keep going on cruises. 👍 Keep eating meat and dairy. 👍 Buy even more stuff. 👍 Nothing to see here. 🤦‍♂️

@breadandcircuses - More like #deathandclowns

#GetRadical #BeTheChange

card.title: Last Sunday was Earth's hottest day in recorded history
card.description: Yet another heat record shattered in the past couple of years, according to the European climate service Copernicus.

descendants.content: Come on people! Nobody is being judged. It’s a genuine question looking for genuine answers. I posted this 40 minutes ago and the poll has had SIX responses. There is no way only six people have seen it. Is this the cognitive dissonance that @heptag0n mentioned in the comments in action?

account.note:

I don't really post much but tend to boost a lot and reply to some. I am interested in #solarpunk, #cycling and #urbanism among other things. I am also developing an interest in #gardening (as much as my tiny balcony allows)

account.note:

Very much my own views etc…

Blog: wifizoo.org

fields.name: Blog
fields.value: https://wifizoo.org

descendants.content: @heptag0n @ethicalrevolution my own direct carbon emission are very low - already drive electric, soon will have efficient electric heating plus solar so my demands on the fairly polluting grid will be significantly reduced. Very rarely fly. I don’t routinely commute anymore. Don’t eat much meat, try to buy local… But is that tinkering around the edges? The sea of plastic that goes into the recycling is certainly depressing.

account.note:

descendants.content: @Wifiwits @heptag0n If the majority of people lived like you it would certainly not be tinkering around the edges. This is what I want to understand here: How do we get more people being like you in the short time we have?

descendants.content:
@Wifiwits @heptag0n Do we not know what to do? On the options in my original question (few of many possible ones:

Do eat meat/Don’t eat meat (and everything in between).

Buy more/Buy less.

Keep flying / Don’t fly.

On those alone we ‘know’ what to do in terms of what is going to be part of any kind of solution, right?

card.title: Accidental Gods  | Growing a Public Chorus for Change: reshaping democracy with Alex Lockwood of the Humanity Project
card.description: We don't have a democracy, we have a kleptocracy that elevates to positions of power those amongst us who are most comfortable with leaning into their inner Dark Triad of Psychopathy, Narcissism and basic low cunning.  Then, when they get there, we're surprised that they go on to wreak havoc with...
card.html: <iframe src="https://share.transistor.fm/e/64eadbe7" width="500" height="180" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" scrolling="no" frameborder="0" sandbox="allow-scripts allow-same-origin allow-popups allow-popups-to-escape-sandbox allow-forms"></iframe>

descendants.content: @urlyman Power structures are of course an issue and we shouldn’t stop challenging them, but there’s no way those in power will make the moves required in the little time we have.

descendants.content: @ethicalrevolution I avoid flying. I avoid buying stuff. I try to buy compostable clothing if I need something new (not easy with plastic in most things). I buy soap bars in cardboard, though the rest of my family prefers pump dispensers. I drive electric because I chose to live semi-rurally. We've planted trees. I eat meat largely because I'm married to a meateater (when he's away, I eat very little meat), but I do still enjoy dairy ... It's hard to be perfect & still live the modern lifestyle.

account.note:
I write. Very slowly.
I read #fiction & #writing research & generally interesting articles.
I listen to music, audiobooks, & podcasts.
I watch things like Spartacus, The Sandman, The Witcher, Brooklyn Nine-Nine, Scrubs, Good Girls, "BreadTube" & reactions to RenMakesMusic, etc
Mother, Lifestyler (ponies & trees!), & technical document compiler (for electricians)
Ōtepoti, Aotearoa.
#Books #Left #NZTwit #MastoWriters #Author #Writer #Fantasy #Fiction #Bookodon #FantasyRomance #NZBooks

descendants.content: @ethicalrevolution That is a question I find super hard to answer. I also spend a lot of time washing recyclables, knowing they will go into a truck with unwashed stuff & likely still end up as rubbish ... But I don't want to be the reason for that. It's often disheartening. I can't not do the things I'm capable of doing, though. The things that are relatively minor inconveniences or low effort ... I can't not do those. How to convince others? 🤷‍♀️

descendants.content: @ethicalrevolution I don't think it's necessarily a case of not being aware of the need for change, but not knowing what is a useful thing to do to help. For example I tried to go vegan as a student in response to learning about the issues of animal agriculture. I was broke, had no time and didn't know a great deal about a healthy diet, I ate chips and peanut butter sandwiches for a week and a half then felt so awful I gave up. I tried again five years ago, and because this time I knew how to

descendants.content: @ethicalrevolution FWIW, and only because you asked… I didn’t answer because I didn’t think any of the choices in the poll were ones that fit me. I do study and believe in the science, and care, and attempt to reduce or eliminate harmful activities accordingly (don’t own a car, eat little meat, reduce-reuse-recycle, etc), short of living like a vegetarian Amish person. And maybe that’s “Other”, but the question was about justifications, and I don’t justify much, so… 🤷‍♂️🙂

account.note: Retired software architect, traveling the world, living out of my backpack. Taoist, Buddhist, reader, gamer, INTJ, scifi/comics/anime fan, queer, mostly ace, and can't taste bitter. Gnostic by nature. 🏳️‍🌈🏳️‍⚧️⚧️🧘‍♂️🖖 🇺🇦

descendants.content: @MythingPerson I think other is probably the answer I want to see the most with the comments such as these included. Just to get a greater understanding. I want us to find solutions. I want to know how I convince my good friend, who flies all over the world an insane amount but is also an incredibly caring human being, to change. Same for many other good friends/family members for same and differing behaviours. I think I do anyway. I mean I don’t know. It’s impossible to be perfect so how far do you go. Is doing one thing ok but not another? My previous mindset was that if we each do better today than we did yesterday in any small way then that’s good. But now it seems the urgency is too great and without radical action our future generations are facing hideous consequences.

descendants.content:
@ethicalrevolution I feel that whole thing. I have a few friends who are great people, but who do things where the harm may be marginal for that specific act, but the overall harm of people doing it is significant. And they just don’t see how *them* doing that thing is bad.

It’s virtually impossible to live a zero-impact life, but I wish more otherwise sensible people were willing to try a little harder. 🤨

descendants.content:
@ethicalrevolution This reminded me of a conversation I had with one of my oldest friends last fall. He’d visited his son and their boyfriend, got to use their VR headset, and fell in love with it, so he bought his own, told me about it, and we had this brief exchange….

I don’t know how you give money to a Facebook company, given their impact on the world. But, hey, it was cheap, right? 🙄🙄🙄

media_attachments.description:
Them:
After paying with Este and DOn's VR set, I have been reading about Metas Quest 3 and bought one! Pre-order as it comes it in like 2 weeks. Costco had a bundle with all sorts of extra stuff like a balancing headband, a game, $25 if credits for more games, a case etc. Very exciting cause unlike nearly anything else it is it own computer so l didn't need to get a gaming OC just to play VR. Reviews so far a awesome, and basically say it like the $4000 next ear Apple one, just 7X less cost and of course not quite as fancy and sharp but given i have never owned one, its a good play to start. Super excited
PS. Yes I hate Meta cause that's wha one does. And whatever privacy if left in my life will be stripped away, but who cares. I'll be dead soon enough

Me:
Your call. 

Them:
Ouch! Much criticism expressed in so few words!

Me:
I strive for efficiency. But, honestly,... meh? When you start with "Yes I hate Meta cause...", and then say, "But I'm giving them money anyway," there's really not much I can say. It's not the way I personally think, but Earth is a land of contrasts. 

Them:
Ouch. Much criticism is so many words!

descendants.content: @MythingPerson It’s so hard.

descendants.content: @ethicalrevolution : Other, because I don't think my circumstances give me a choice. I am poor and disabled, so that means my impact is oftentimes small (I never travel, I don't drive nor own a car, I can't afford to buy beyond my essential needs if that), but the impact I do have, I feel powerless to decrease (for instance I don't own a fridge nor have the ability to cook much, so I buy the cheapest food I can easily store & prepare, without changing my habits regarding meat). Stuff like that.

account.note:
French tooting in English only (but boosting in more languages, translate function ftw !).
Permanent #CW for depression & anxiety, child abuse, PTSD, disability, agoraphobia, poverty. Profile counts as terms & conditions ! XD

descendants.content: @ethicalrevolution : I often feel guilty because I wonder whether I'm rationalizing my behavior. But at the same time I feel stuck. When I use simulations of my ecologicl impact, usually the biggest "footprint" comes from my housing's energy consumption but I'm in social housing and can hardly choose how to make a change. Or at least so I think ? Maybe I use it as an excuse, sometimes I'm not sure. Maybe it's convenient to hide behind poverty and disability.

descendants.content: @ethicalrevolution ...On my bad days I'm actually angry at all the "be responsible" talk when directed at me because my life is limited in so many ways, I shouldn't be the one to sacrifice more for the future, when noone cares about my present living conditions and that of people like me. It's not always, and I do try to be mindful where I can, but every once in a while I just get bitter, like, my cans of corned beef are not driving us to extinction.
